Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 02:46PM Rshep9101 wrote: It's been over a month since I started this thread and my excisional is in a couple of days.  My breast pain has at times been agonizing and recently the pain started to intensify in the arm pit area.  I have woken up with a swollen achey feeling in it for the past 6 days.  The levels of pain/ache vary at times radiating to my bicep and breast.  After not being able to sleep Tues night due to pain and OTC relievers not working they called me in some Hydrocodone.  I did not ask for this but this was their only real response to my calls about the consistent pain.  So....I gave in and filled the script.  Sometimes the meds help sometimes they don't.  I have my pre-op stuff on Mon. and surgery on Tues.  I have so many questions and I don't know if I will actually see the Dr. on Monday.  I doubt it.  I'm a little nervous but mostly I want this whole ordeal over.  It's been almost two months since I first saw the gyno and began scheduling appts.  My prayer is just for some conclusive findings after the surgery.  I went and got my zip front bra and am trying to prepare for the unknown.  I've never had any kind of surgery.  The stereotactic was really hard for me both during and after so I'm hoping for the best and preparing for the worst.
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications & ALH - HELP!! Rshep9101 Rshep9101

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2010 09:52AM Rshep9101 wrote: Worried Woman-  We are in a similar situation it seems.  I will be happy to answer any questions you have about the surgery but be forewarned I am more convinced than ever that I have had much more pain associated with all my procedures than is average.  Every person's experience is an individual one but that said the info from many on here helped me prepare mentally.  Some of it was the same and some of it was different.  I am one week post surgery and jogged(barely, while holding my breast with my forearm and wearing this crazy tight high impact bra) about 1 mile today and walked about 1/2 mile.  I also know that I'll need some meds pretty soon.  Many said that they were ready to go back to work within 24 hours.  Personally it was several days before I was able to get out at all and then it could only be at my own pace and for short periods of time.  I tend to tire quickly and then the pain increases.  I drove for the first time yesterday and it was a little tiring to be stuck in traffic for a hour.  I had surgery on my left breast and am also left handed so that complicates things.  Good luck with your stereotactic.  I found that the stereotactic was worse afterwards than the surgery but maybe that's the drugs :)  I also believe that the source of my pain was removed during surgery and that is why although I have hurt and been very weary my pain has significantly improved.  For me the wire placement was the worst but I think that was because of whatever that lump was.  I told the mammo tech it makes sense I would be in severe pain, they just shoved a large needle into the spot where most of my pain has been for a year!  Good Luck!  Wishing you Benign results as well!

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 09:47AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:18AM by Rshep9101 Thanks leaf and to everyone who has been kind, supportive, and willing to answer my questions so far.  On Tues. I had my wire guided excisional biopsy.  I thought that I would be getting one wire but it turns out there are now more microcalcifications than there were a month ago.  So, I got to have two wires.  Which by the way were almost the most painful thing in the world.  I had lidocaine but still felt the majority or the procedure and as soon as I was out of compression and blood was flowing again my body began shaking from the pain.  It was the worst!  I don't get why I am having so much pain with procedures that most women on here sailed through with only minor discomfort!  The techs also had trouble getting my images prior to wire placement because that area is now even more dense than it was before!  The hospital staff was amazing!  I've never had a surgery or spent any real time in a hospital as a patient and their kindness helped me get through the difficult day.   I saw my surgeon right before surgery and she mentioned the possibility of a cyst caused by fibrocystic changes for the first time(as an explanation) for the pain, but also said that ALH can cause pain.  This was new.  She said that the rapidly reproducing cells can cause pain but that is different info that I had received from just about everywhere else.  She did not know that they had given me two wires until that point and offered no explanation of the new micros.  I believe she heard me when I told her I will NOT exist in a state requiring me to take Hydrocodone and Tylenol all the time.  She saw my husband after surgery and all she said was that there definitely were a lot of fibrocystic changes going on in my breast.  That's all she said really though.  Do hormones cause fibrocystic changes?  I know that my gynos response to my hormone issues was the pill and getting rid of my cycle completely but with the ALH diagnosis I have been encouraged to stay far away from any form of estrogen.  Who knows what the answer will be?  I guess it depends on what the pathology reports say.  My DH had to go back to work yesterday and I knew people would be coming by later in the day so I got up and did laundry and cleaned the house some, until my muscles starting shaking and I felt like I was going to faint.  I've been pushing through so much pain for so long that I forget that surgery recovery is more than just how much pain I am coping with.  My body has to heal!  I am under strict orders to DO NOTHING!  Pretty hard for me.  I expect to hear something either today or tomorrow.  Hoping for good, conclusive findings!

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 09:39PM Rshep9101 wrote: Hi rn4babies, I too would expect them to do a biopsy.  I have a suspicious cluster of microcals that were seen via diagnostic mammo.  I also have a strong family hx.  Great aunt died of BC, Grandmother died of OC, older sister(32) tested positive for BRCA and has had a lot of surgeries since she was 16 some lumps having precancerous cells.  Since finding out about my sister's hx in particular they have been more aggressive with my process. I get the impression they aren't going to make any assumptions.  My surgeon has also already mentioned genetic testing and tamoxifen.   I have since had an ultrasound, a stereotactic biopsy and am awaiting a surgical biopsy on the 30th.  I'll be thinking of you and I'm wishing good peaceful thoughts.  I hope you are able to get some answers that will give you either a sense of "what to do now" or even better, a peace.
Posts.Title: I know the stats but still worried..... rn4babies rn4babies

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 07:46PM - edited Nov 3, 2010 11:16PM by Rshep9101  The procedure for many seems virtually painless based on the majority of the posts so you will probably experience the same.  However, for me that was not the experience.  I knew I had sensitive breasts but apparently they are very sensitive.  The radiologist said I received the same amount of lidocaine as usually given but I felt continuous sharp pain throughout the procedure.  Having never had the procedure I didn't know what was normal pain to experience, I also was not informed to ask for more lidocaine if I needed it.  Luckily they were very fast and professional.  My pain tolerance is very high and I was in a lot pain for about 24 hours the worst being the first 2-3 hours.  After that the pain was on and off from sharp to dull ache pain for about a week.  I am a runner and ran 6 days after procedure and was sore afterwards.  It has been getting better gradually. I am three weeks post biopsy and still bruised.  My breast was so bruised that the surgeon commented on it last week.  I also have a hematoma.  I have yet to read a post describing these type of negative side effects associated with a sterotactic biopsy so maybe I am a unique situation.  My advice is if you feel sharp continuous pain during the biopsy make them give you more lidocaine. I had my son naturally and compare all pain to that, and compared to that this even at it's worst is totally doable   Good Luck!

Today I had my 5th biopsy(2 core needles, 1 stereo tactic, and 2 Excisional surgeries) I am exhausted emotionally. Everytime they find something and we have to go through all this we talk about BMX. I have a lifetime risk of 47% but was BRCA negative. In one week I have had an MRI, mammo, ultrasound, core needle biopsy, clip placement, and another mammo. I am scared of losing all feeling in my breasts after the BMX. can anyone who has made this difficult choice speak about that...
Posts.Title: Prophylactic Mastectomy bruinjamie21 trina21

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 04:07PM Rshep9101 wrote: Yes, there's a chance that could happen.  I am 30 years old with very dense breasts, (like many younger women but even more so) so my breast tissue shows up as white on the mammos instead of grey like the more common fatty adipose tissue.  The problem is that cancer and sometimes benign lumps show up white on the images making it very difficult to differentiate between a mass and regular dense tissue.  I know all this because I have a palpable lump that was not detected on a diagnostic mammo or an ultrasound but my breast surgeon has felt.  I did have a cluster of microcalcifications that were visible on the mammo and ultrasound which can be a sign that something else suspicious is going on nearby.  If the lump does not show up on either mammo or u/s I would see a breast surgeon(they are the specialists).  They might take a "wait and see" approach, depending on your breast density and family hx they might suggest an MRI.  I know it seems like a stretch given your age and most lumps in younger women are benign but trust me....have it checked out.  I went in for discharge and breast pain, they found a cluster of microcalcifications, atypical lobular hyperplasia, and now I'm having a surgical biopsy in a week.  You'll feel better after having it checked out, you probably will worry either way.  Beware of the density issue.  Good luck!  Let us know how it goes!

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2010 10:01AM - edited Nov 19, 2010 12:31PM by Rshep9101 I don't really understand the micro-calcification thing.  I think they are the residue occurring when there is too much cell division/reproduction.  If that is right how would the microcalcs themselves be benign or malignant.  In my situation they took 3(out of 20-35) micro-calcification samples at the stereotactic.  The radiologist said those were benign but they found ALH.  If there were malignant cells would they cause the microcalcs to be malignant?  Calcification's aren't cells are they?  Or is this just a matter of looking in the right spot?  I think I'm confused.
Posts.Title: Regarding 80% biopsies being negative gsaid10 Rshep9101

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2018 07:52PM - edited Nov 9, 2018 08:02PM by Rshep9101 hello there, I completely understand your feelings. The waiting. The wondering. The hypothetical responses to hypothetical test results. I am also 38 and was diagnosed with ALH, Fibrocystic breast changes, and dense breasts 8 years ago. My older sister is BRCA positive so it made me even more high risk. I have endured the same type of screening as you and am about to have my 4th biopsy (2nd Surgical) in 8 years. It is nerve wracking. I too have a background in science as a Nutritionist so I want all the info possible. it helps me have an idea of how I would respond in certain hypothetical situations. I love my surgeon. She is calm, conservative when it comes to surgery, and so willing to respectfully answer any and all of my questions. She has helped me tremendously over these years. I just had genetic testing yesterday and am scheduled for surgery next Thursday to remove a growing fibroadenoma. The waiting will be the worst. I am an emotional person. I will spend some time on these boards and reading journal studies, which will be positive some days and negative for me on other days. I will watch old shows again that I have seen a million times (ie Grey's, Felicity, etc). I pray a lot and cry a lot. I write down gratitudes. I box and channel all my feelings into punching the bag. I play basketball and lift weights. I made a playlist specifically for changing my mood. I cook. I will throw myself into Christmas shopping and decorate a week or two earlier than most ;). My first surgery was also in November. Depending on the results of my genetic testing I may reach a point that I am ready to reduce my risk with surgery(oopherectomy or mastectomy). I am not there yet but the worry, waiting, anxiety, and screenings effect different people in different ways. My sister sees them as just routine tasks at this point but she started this journey at 16. She is single and doesn't have any kids so the risk though very real is hers alone. I tell my family if a biopsy is needed but I don't call everyone. I have tried over these last few years to be more transparent about my risk and screening because I think it reminds my peers that they should not assume their age removes them from risk. Good luck to you as you navigate all this. Cancer sucks. Being High Risk sucks too. hugs 😊
